title: Dad has huge slab of his neck removed after skin cancer diagnosis
text:
The father-of-two had a slab of his neck removed after a sun spot was diagnosed as skin cancer (Picture: Ryan Glossop/Facebook)

An Australian man who had to have a huge chunk of flesh removed is urging sun worshippers to get their skin checked.

Ryan Glossop, 37, from Perth, initially went to have a freckle looked at by doctors, and was diagnosed with Melanoma, a type of cancer.

He underwent several surgeries on the area, but doctors eventually decided to remove a large part of his neck and back after his tests kept coming back with abnormal results.

A strip of skin reportedly 40cm long and 8cm wide had to be grafted from his legs to cover the surface of his neck.

Now on the mend, the health and safety adviser is hoping his story can help others.

Mr Glossop initially went to get an innocuous-looking freckle checked (Picture: A little beauty/Facebook)

He eventually had four surgeries on the area (Picture: A little beauty/Facebook)

The Aussie 37-year-old is now urging sunbathers to get their skin checked (Picture: A little beauty/Facebook)

Mr Glossop’s friend had advised him to get the mole checked after losing a friend to the condition.

Since undergoing the surgery, he now wants to take the ‘opportunity to motivate at least one person to have a skin scan and potentially save a life’.

He told Yahoo News Australia: ‘I was fortunate to have a skin check at work. Fortunately for me the rest is in the past and I’m moving forward. But please have a skin check.’

Mr Glossop continued: ‘Going through that was scary at first, but then once they said “if we can get this skin graft done, we think you’ll be in the clear”, it was more dealing with the fact I’d have fairly significant scars.

‘It’s a common perception that melanoma, although can be deadly, can be removed pretty easily and there’s only a small scar.’

The Glossops are urging the public to be more conscious of Melanoma (Picturer: Ryan Glossop/Facebook)

A strip of skin reportedly 40cm long and 8cm wide was taken from his legs to cover the patch of his neck and back (Picture: A little beauty/Facebook)

After his diagnosis in November 2018, Mr Glossop had around 40 biopsies of his neck and back, one of his lung and then four surgeries on the area.

His latest surgery, in May, involved the removal of a large strips of skin from his neck and legs.

In a Facebook post, wife Fallon explained: ‘With any skin cancer, not only do they remove the affected area of skin, but they also take a boundary around it.

‘Ryan’s boundaries kept coming back abnormal, which was then found to be a skin condition called Nevus Spilus. It’s very rare for it to transition into melanoma, but in his case it did.

‘In May 2019 a large area of skin from his neck and back needed to be taken. So in his 4th surgery, Ryan had a skin graft, removing skin from both legs to cover (the) section on his neck and back.’

Praising his strength, she went on: ‘This whole experience has been hugely challenging for all of us, but if anything good is to come out of this, it is that we now want to help raise more awareness of skin cancer.

‘Melanoma accounts for 10 per cent of all skin cancers, which is why it is so important that everyone has regular skin checks.

‘Your life is too precious to just bake yourself in the sun and not worry about your skin.’
